title: 103_s384
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Loan Securitization and Secondary Market Enhancement Act of 1993". It pertains to small business related security. The "Small Business Loan Securitization and Secondary Market Enhancement Act of 1993" defines a small business related security as a security rated in the top four categories by a recognized organization, representing an interest in promissory notes from a small business or secured by an interest in assets. The "Small Business Loan Securitization and Secondary Market Enhancement Act of 1993" defines a small business related security as an interest in promissory notes from a small business, with criteria for small business concern established under the Small Business Act. The Small Business Act is amended under section 3(a) to include a definition of "penny stocks" after redesignating a paragraph in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 3. APPLICABILITY OF MARGIN REQUIREMENTS. Amends the Securities Exchange Act to include "small business related security" in margin requirements. SEC. 4. BORROWING IN THE COURSE OF BUSINESS. Amends the Act to include "small business related security" in borrowing provisions. SEC. 5. SMALL BUSINESS RELATED SECURITIES AS COLLATERAL. Amends the Act to include "small business related security" as collateral. SEC. 6. INVESTMENT BY DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS. The Home Owners' Loan Act is amended to allow investments in small business related securities, subject to regulations. The Federal Credit Union Act is also amended to include provisions for small business related securities. The Home Owners' Loan Act and the Federal Credit Union Act are amended to include provisions for small business related securities, subject to regulations set by the Board. National Banking Associations are also affected by the amendments, allowing investments in small business related securities. SEC. 7. PREEMPTION OF STATE LAW. Section 106(a)(1) and 106(a)(2) of the Secondary Mortgage Market Enhancement Act of 1984 are amended to include small business related securities as defined in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The amendment includes small business related securities in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, expanding the scope of exemptions from state laws. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment exempts small business related securities from state laws for 7 years if a state enacts a statute with more limited authority on purchasing, holding, or investing in such securities. Any existing contractual commitments are not affected by the state statute. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment exempts small business related securities from state laws for 7 years if a state enacts a statute with different terms. SEC. 8. Insured depository institution capital requirements for transfers of small business loans and investments in small business related securities. The accounting principles for transferring small business loans with recourse must align with generally accepted accounting principles. Capital requirements for insured depository institutions selling small business loans with recourse should not exceed the estimated liability. Small business related securities are treated similarly to mortgage-backed securities under risk-based capital requirements. The regulations require each appropriate Federal banking agency to implement capital standards for insured depository institutions selling small business loans with recourse within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. Definitions for terms like "appropriate Federal banking agency" and "insured depository institution" are provided in the section. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms such as "other capital measures," "recourse," "small business," and "small business related security." These definitions are important for understanding the regulations related to capital standards for insured depository institutions selling small business loans with recourse. SEC. 9. Transactions in small business related securities by employee benefit plans. The Secretary of Labor, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, may exempt transactions involving small business related securities from certain restrictions and taxes. Considerations include facilitating transactions and protecting the rights of participants and beneficiaries. The Secretary of Labor will promulgate final regulations within 180 days to protect the rights and interests of participants and beneficiaries of the plan. SEC. 10. TAXATION OF SMALL BUSINESS LOAN INVESTMENT CONDUITS. The Secretary of the Treasury will create regulations for taxing small business loan investment conduits similar to real estate mortgage investment conduits under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Adjustments will be made to REMIC provisions to facilitate securitization of small business loans and develop a secondary market for them. A small business loan investment conduit is defined as an entity whose assets primarily consist of obligations from small business concerns. This definition includes obligations originated by insured depository institutions. The regulations for taxing small business loan investment conduits will be similar to those for real estate mortgage investment conduits, with adjustments made to facilitate securitization and develop a secondary market for small business loans. A small business loan investment conduit is an entity whose assets consist of obligations from small business concerns, including those originated by supervised financial institutions.
